71852.title: pair of gloves
71852.description: A pair of red and white checked gloves; gloves cut and sewn from a red and white gingham patterned elastic fabric and a white cotton knit; top of hands and thumbs in bias cut gingham; the balance of the gloves in white cotton knit; the gloves are short, ending just above the wrist; the wrist edge is cut in a curve that ends in a small outward flare at the outer side of the wrist; the wrist hem is finished with a white cotton knit binding that appears like corded piping; 6 ½ is printed in medium gray inside each glove on the white cotton knit at the bottom side of the wrist; the gloves are packaged in a transparent plastic sleeve printed overall with a light blue grid pattern on top of which CLAIRE McCARDELL is printed in a red-orange
71852.credit_line: Gift of David Sheflin, Vintage Fashion Inc.
71852.provenance: David Sheflin, Vintage Fashion Inc., Phoenix, Arizona; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2011 (TR11257/1A-B).
71852.inscription: label on packaging: CLAIRE McCARDELL (printed in a red orange)

71889.title: pair of gloves
71889.description: pair of ladies dress black and white gingham gloves A pair of black and white checked gloves; gloves cut and sewn from a black and white gingham patterned synthetic fabric and a white cotton knit; top of hands and thumbs in bias cut gingham; the balance of the gloves in white cotton knit; the gloves are short, ending just above the wrist; the wrist edge is cut in a curve that ends in a small outward flare at the outer side of the wrist; the wrist hem is finished with a white cotton knit binding that appears like corded piping; the gloves are packaged in a transparent plastic sleeve printed overall with a light blue grid pattern on top of which CLAIRE McCARDELL is printed in a red-orange.
71889.credit_line: Gift of David Sheflin, Vintage Fashion Inc.
71889.provenance: David Sheflin, Vintage Fashion Inc., Phoenix, Arizona; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2011 (TR11257/2A-B).
71889.inscription: label on packaging: CLAIRE McCARDELL (printed in a red orange)

72992.title: textile; 'Hardcore' (Burnout '88 collection)
72992.description: A 43 x 50 rectangle of light blue light weight crepe backed satin weave silk fabric with a very narrow machine stitched hem around all four edges; the fabric is silkscreened with dot screen separation photographic images of a group of men in dark orange and black dye; a woven label, SPROUSE in black on a white ground is stitched to the back of the proper left edge of the panel near the top corner.
72992.provenance: (Leslie Hindman Auctioneers, Chicago, Illinois), 20 September 2011, lot 634; purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2011.

52370.title: Tile
52370.description: Group of five square or round encaustic tiles with conventional leaf-like unit repeated four times abut a 6 inch diameter center and inlaid.  In this group of five tiles, some have two colors and some have three colors of cream clay and gray blue or light red.  One has red and gray with black and white center.  Four are marked "United States Encaustic Tile Works, Indpls."
52370.credit_line: Gift of United States Encaustic Tile Works
52370.provenance: United States Encaustic Tile Works, Indianapolis, Indiana

4441.title: Maria and Baby
4441.creation_notes: A recent loan request suggested that the date was "ca. 1916" and that the painting, which depicts Maria Martinez, was completed during the 1915-16 Panama-California Exposition. However, the curator was unable to provide evidence to support this date change. Valerie Ann Leeds's dissertation on Henri and the American Southwest gives the 1917 date of creation.
4441.credit_line: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
4441.provenance:
Estate of the artist, New York; (Hirschl & Adler Galleries, Inc., New York); Nicholas Woloshuk, Santa Fe, New Mexico; (Kennedy Galleries, New York); (Hirschl & Adler Galleries, New York) in 1969;{1} Harrison Eiteljorg, Indianapolis; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1976.

{1} The early provenance is recorded in Gerald Peters Gallery, Santa Fe, New York, Dallas, Robert Henri in Santa Fe: his work and influence, October 10-24, 1998, plate 38.
4441.exhibit_history: "Robert Henri in Santa Fe: His Art and Influence," Gerald Peters Gallery, Santa Fe, New Mexico, 10/10/1998-10/24/1998  |  "Art of the American West (The West as Inspiration)," Eiteljorg Museum of the American Indian and Western Art, Indianapolis, Indiana,05/1989-06/09/1998  |  "The Painters of Taos:  Selections from the Collection of Harrison Eiteljorg," Sierra Nevada Museum of Art, Reno, Nevada, 06/25/1985-08/18/1985  |  "The Painters of Taos:  Selections from the Collection of Harrison Eiteljorg," Palm Springs Desert Museum, Palm Springs, California, 11/01/1984-03/30/1985

83876.title: In the Garden
83876.credit_line: Gift of the Estate of Charlotte Hofmann Bose
83876.provenance:
Probably purchased from the artist by Carl H. Leiber [1866-1929], Indianapolis, Indiana, between 1916 and 1920; {1} Mrs. Carl Lieber [1871-1960], née Meta Pantzer, Indianapolis, Indiana; {2} to her daughter, Lili Lieber Hofmann [1895-1970], Indianapolis, Indiana, after 1934; to her daughter, Charlotte Bose [1920-2013], Indianapolis, Indiana; given by her estate to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 2014.

{1} The loan card for the Twenty-third Exhibition of American Art at the Cincinnati Art Museum, May 26 to July 31, 1916, which included In the Garden, cat. no. 76, indicates that the painting was owned by the artist. In the Garden was displayed in an exhibition at the Herron Art Institute titled Paintings by William Forsyth, November 7-28, 1920, cat. no. 8; see Rachel Berenson Perry, William J. Forsyth: The Life and Work of an Indiana Artist, Bloomington, 2014, p. 127. On November 14, 1920, The Indianapolis Star listed Carl Lieber as a lender to the exhibition; see Lucille E. Morehouse, Forsyths Work Wins Praise at Art Institute, Indianapolis Star, November 14, 1920, p. 37. 
{2} On the IMAs Temporary Receipt No. 3105 for an exhibition titled Retrospective of William Forsyth at the Herron Art Institute in 1934, Mrs. Carl H. Lieber was listed as the lender of In the Garden.  See also The Bulletin of the Art Association of Indianapolis Vol. XXI, December 1934, p. 7.
83876.inscription: signed and dated, l.r.: W. Forsyth 91
83876.exhibit_history: Twenty-third Exhibition of American Art, Cincinnati Art Museum, Cincinnati, Ohio, 1916, no. 76  |  Seventeenth Annual Exhibition, Art Association of Indianapolis, Indianapolis, Indiana, 1900, no. 34  |  Fourth Annual Exhibition, Society of Western Artists, St. Louis Museum of Fine Arts, St. Louis, Missouri, 1899  |   Worlds Columbian Exposition, Chicago, Illinois, 1893, no. 12, likely under the title, The Rhubarb Patch
